Rules: (AR 1.7.1, B-2)\par When drawing 2 race destiny instead of 1, the Light Side player is permitted to stack (use) both of them on Anakin's Podracer. The decision to use a race destiny is made immediately after one is drawn. (See Podracing, Ap. C) This Podracer will automatically "schedule" three race destiny draws if Anakin's Podracer is behind at any time during the Light Side player's draw phase. Next turn, the Light Side player must draw three and must choose (use) two of them to stack on the Podracer. These scheduled race destiny draws can still be restricted by subsequent actions, for example, the Dark Side playing Hit Racer.

Deploy on Podrace Arena. Once per game, either player may initiate a Podrace: During your control phase, each player may draw one race destiny. Each player may place any drawn race destiny on their Podracer (or on Podrace Arena if they have none) or in their Used Pile. During any move phase, winner is any player with a race total > 24 and greater than opponent's highest race total. Winner retrieves 6 Force and loser loses 6 Force. Rules: (AR 1.7.1, F-3)\par Podracing - Race Destiny And Race Total \par If a podrace is not being run, treat all race totals as being an unmodifiable 0. This is a specific exception to the normal rules of undefined values. "Here" on a podracer refers to a race destiny stacked on that podracer, not any other. For example, when Dud Bolt's Podracer is lost, only the race destinies stacked on that podracer are placed in Used Pile.\par -----\par (AR 1.7.1, B-2)\par While you are free to use your opponent's copy of this card to initiate a podrace (even if both are in play), you must specifically note this at the time you initiate the podrace. If you do not, you are assumed to be using your own copy. The winner of a podracer is determined automatically when either player has a race total > 24 at any time during any move phase.

Lore: Sebulba is willing to utilize a variety of 'tactics' to maintain his lead position. Mars Guo learned this lesson the hard way.
Gametext: During your control phase, use 2 Force to target opponent's Podracer with a race total within 4 of one of your race totals. Draw destiny. If destiny > target Podracer's destiny number, opponent may not draw race destiny this turn and target Podracer is 'damaged.'
Information: Now you can use the same devious methods to win a podrace that Sebulba tried in the film. During your Control Phase, you can attempt to damage and slow down an opponent's Podracer whose race total is within 4 of your own. This means you can either try to overtake a racer who is slightly ahead of yours, or you can try to create a setback for a racer gaining on one of your own. Since race destiny is drawn during the Dark Side's Control Phase, the Dark Side player has the option of playing this card before or after race destinies are drawn, although playing Hit Racer first is wise, since you may eliminate your opponent's race destiny this turn.\par \par If you successfully damage your opponent's racer, you get the immediate benefit of causing the Light Side to skip a race destiny. But even better than that is the added game text. Until the target racer is repaired, the Light Side will have to lose 1 Force in order to use any race destiny. This will potentially cause them to gradually fall behind your racer as they make hard decisions about what race destinies to keep.\par \par This card is probably best used when you are within reach of winning the race. After all, since the Light Side will retrieve 6 Force for winning the race (and even more if they're playing with cards like I Did It!), he probably won't mind losing a couple of Force in order to use race destinies that will take him across the finish line first.\par \par Of course, your opponent will need to be playing Anakin's Podracer for this to work, since Hit Racer cannot be played on a generic podracer. But with the importance that racing is likely to have in the game, it shouldn't be surprising to see Anakin's Podracer showing up in many decks.

Lore: Vader had to show Luke that giving in to the dark side of the Force was his only destiny.
Gametext: USED: If a battle was just initiated where you have a character armed with a lightsaber, characters may not be targeted by lightsabers for remainder of battle. LOST: If opponent just initiated a duel, opponent must choose to lose 4 Force or cancel the duel.
Information: The Lost game text on this Used or Lost Interrupt is, well, a little lost on us for the moment. A dueling version of Projective Telepathy, this card makes the Light Side choose to either lose 4 Force or cancel a duel they just initiated. At the moment, there are only two ways for the Light Side to initiate a duel. The first is through Jedi Test #6, a strategy not seen very often. The second (and more likely to be seen) is the Interrupt from Tatooine, You'll Find I'm Full Of Surprises, which gives Luke some dueling ability. Lightsaber Parry will be useful against this card, as well as any future duel-initiating ability the Light Side might gain in the future.\par \par Lightsaber Parry also provides some interesting Used game text. If the Dark Side has a lightsaber in a just-initiated battle, this card will eliminate the ability of all lightsabers present to target characters. At first glance, this might seem a little silly. After all, while the Light Side won't be slicing and dicing, the Dark Side can't use their lightsabers, either. But there is a method to the madness. The Light Side still outnumbers the Dark in number of characters who can use the various unique lightsabers. In addition, the Light Side has a little more versatility, with Anakin's Lightsaber being usable by either Luke or Leia. These facts add up to a decent chance that the Light Side will have more lightsabers in a battle than the Dark Side. Now, sacrificing Darth Maul's chance to hit an opponent is more than offset by the fact that you have saved several of your characters from the blade.\par \par This text can also be useful when you have an important character with a low defense value in the battle. Characters with 1, 2, or even 3 ability are almost sure to be hit by a lightsaber. Now your Dark Jedi can keep that character alive and kicking for at least another turn. And since this part of Lightsaber Parry is a Used Interrupt, your Dark Jedi will be able to come to the rescue again, and again, and again...

Lore: Good-willed Mon Calamari merchant. Looking for work. Unfortunately, everywhere he goes he comes up empty handed.
Gametext: Power +X in a battle at a site, where X equals the number of cards in opponent's hand. During your deploy phase, opponent may place any number of cards in their hand in their Used Pile.
Information: Mon Calamari are:\par \par Admiral Ackbar\par Admiral Ackbar (V)\par Captain Verrack\par First Officer Thaneespi\par Loci Rosen\par Major Haash'n\par -----\par This Mon Calamari has the potential to have enormous power. He does have a drawback of allowing your opponent to recycle cards, but he will really make your opponent think how many cards he really needs in hand. After all, one more card in his hand could mean one more battle damage coming his way.\par \par But the key to using him effectively is to get him into battle when your opponent doesn't see it coming. If you deploy him to a probable battle location, you can be sure his power will be taken down a notch before the battle. You will want to use cards that let him get to a battle without you deploying him to the battle location on your turn. For example, on Cloud City you can use Path of Least Resistance to get him where he's needed, or in Jabba's Palace you could use You Will Take Me to Jabba Now.
IsPulled: Admiral Ackbar

Lore: "Wha-? Chuba da noya!"
Gametext: USED: During battle, place top card of opponent's Lost Pile on top of their Reserve Deck. LOST: Use 1 Force to 'repair' your Podracer. OR Target a Podracer. Draw destiny. If destiny > Podracer's destiny number, target is 'damaged.'
Information: You've always had the chance to stack your own destiny draws, but now you have the chance to stack your opponent's as well. If there's going to be a crucial destiny draw in a battle (and what battle doesn't?), you can stack a low destiny on top of your opponent's deck. You are retrieving a Force for your opponent, but he won't be thanking you when Admiral Ozzel is flipped for battle destiny.\par \par The lost portion can also be useful in a podracing deck. You can repair your Podracer so you don't need to lose Force to keep the race going, or you can take a shot at damaging your opponent's Podracer to make him pay the price to stay in the race.
IsPulled: We Wish To Board At Once

Lore: Advanced optics used by Darth Maul to help track Queen Amidala. Image enhancement features allow for better sensor readings.
Gametext: Use 2 Force to deploy on Maul. At any time you may use 1 Force to peek at the top card of your Force Pile. You may move that card to the top of your Reserve Deck.
Information: They only deploy on Maul, but he should be in your deck anyway, right? And while the actual mechanic of fixing destiny is a bit different when compared to the Light Side, the raw power of it is still there.\par While Maul's Electrobinoculars will eat up your Force Pile fast, the Dark Side also has an infinite number of situations where fixing up a destiny would be desirable, i.e., before a duel, or before drawing race/battle/weapon destiny.\par You can also get to that one crucial card in your Force Pile without junking up your hand. Pay a Force to look, if it's not the card you need put it back, and continue the process until you get to the card you need!
Combo: Maul's Electrobinoculars + any card that initiates a duel\par Guarantee yourself a solid start on any duel you initiate. A great deal, considering winning a duel is a rather large step toward victory in any game!

Lore: Trained in the Sith arts, Maul's ferocity in combat is matched by no other. When armed with a lightsaber, his opponent's only option is usually that of escape.
Gametext: Deploy on Maul. While on Maul, may not be stolen. May add 1 to Force drain where present. May target a character or creature. Draw two destiny. Target hit, and its forfeit = 0, if total destiny > defense value.
Information: Maul's lightsaber 'personas' are:\par \par Maul's Double-Bladed Lightsaber\par Maul's Lightsaber\par Darth Maul With Lightsaber\par Lord Maul With Lightsaber\par  -----\par When Maul is using this weapon, it cannot be stolen. This simple bit of gametext protects Maul's Lightsaber from annoying interrupts like Weapon Levitation, that can result in the Dark Side suddenly finding itself weaponless in a battle.\par \par In addition, Maul can make excellent use of his weapon. Darth Maul (Tatooine Expansion) can effectively ignore the presence of Light Side characters of ability less than 4. This means he can Force drain while at their site, using Maul's Lightsaber to add 1 to the Force drain. He can also use cards like Sniper to take pot-shots at those poor, low-ability characters, gradually reducing their numbers at his site. Light Side alien swarm decks will want to avoid this armed Dark Jedi as much as possible.\par \par Finally, like other lightsabers, Maul's Lightsaber gets two weapons destiny draws, making it easier to hit even high-ability characters like Obi-Wan and Qui-Gon. Maul also has the advantage of using Maul's Electrobinoculars to rig a high destiny draw, practically guaranteeing a hit against even a Jedi Master if you take the time!
IsPulled: I Will Finish What You Started\par Maul Strikes
MatchingWeapon: Darth Maul\par Darth Maul With Lightsaber\par Darth Maul, Lone Hunter\par Darth Maul, Young Apprentice\par Lord Maul\par Lord Maul With Lightsaber

Lore: When Anakin had finally caught up with Sebulba, he knew he needed to make some kind of a move to break away from the Dug and win the race.
Gametext: If difference between opponent's and your highest race totals < 4, lose 1 Force. Opponent draws no race destiny next control phase. OR If both players have < 10 Life Force remaining, both players retrieve 4 Force.

Lore: "Your buddy here was about to be turned into orange goo. He picked a fight with a Dug. An especially dangerous Dug called Sebulba."
Gametext: Deploy on table. Once per turn may use 1 Force to look through opponent's Lost Pile and place all docking bays you find there out of play. Once per game may deploy Sebulba from Reserve Deck; reshuffle. (Immune to Alter.)
Information: Startable with Prepared Defenses.
Pulls: Sebulba
IsPulled: Twi'lek Advisor\par We Must Accelerate Our Plans

Lore: Qui-Gon Jinn's Padawan. Stayed behind to protect Queen Amidala when Qui-Gon left to explore Mos Espa, but was in constant communication should he be needed.
Gametext: Deploys -2 to Tatooine. If opponent just initiated a battle at a related Tatooine site, may use 2 Force to relocate Obi-Wan to that site. Immune to attrition < 4.
Information: Obi-Wan Kenobi personas are:\par \par Ben Kenobi\par Obi-Wan in Radiant VII\par Obi-Wan Kenobi\par Obi-Wan Kenobi (V)\par Obi-Wan Kenobi, Jedi Knight\par Obi-Wan Kenobi, Padawan Learner\par Obi-Wan Kenobi, Padawan Learner (V)\par Obi-Wan With Lightsaber
IsPulled: Fall Of A Jedi\par Padme Naberrie\par Return Of A Jedi
Combo: Obi-Wan Kenobi, Padawan Learner + Krayt Dragon Howl

Lore: Queen Amidala posed as one of her own handmaidens for added safety as well as to keep an eye on her Jedi protectors. Was to be protected by the Jedi at all times.
Gametext: Twice per game may deploy Qui-Gon or Obi-Wan here from Reserve Deck; reshuffle. While present with your Jedi at a site, opponent may not target Amidala with weapons.
Information: Amidala personas are:\par \par Padme Naberrie\par Padme Naberrie (V)\par Queen Amidala\par Queen Amidala, Ruler Of Naboo\par -----\par Power 3, Ability 3, destiny 3 and Forfeit 5 - all for 2 deploy! Statistics alone are a very solid reason to consider the disguised Queen for your deck! But there's more!\par \par For one thing, this version of the Amidala persona is a Republic character, thus unaffected by anything that targets Rebels. For example, Charming To The Last, Put All Sections On Alert and the popular Scum deck helper, None Shall Pass, all fall flat when faced with this Republican.\par \par Of course, her real kicker is in her game text. Besides the fact that her Jedi protectors keep her safe from weapon fire, she can even 'download' them! Twice per game, deploy Qui-Gon or Obi-Wan to Padme's site. That's a very fast way to get out any version of two of your biggest characters. And of course, you could just use it to get Qui-Gon twice to stall an opponent's Hunt Down, or perhaps Ben Kenobi twice to push your Profit deck along.\par \par So what are her disdvantages? Only one, but it is red, black and nasty - Darth Maul is looking for her. But even then, Padme benefits - if Dark Side is playing a 'Hunt The Queen' strategy (I Will Find Them Quickly Master and the Epic Event, If The Trace Was Correct) then she can deploy straight from your Reserve Deck.
Pulls: Ben Kenobi\par  Obi-Wan Kenobi\par Obi-Wan Kenobi (V)\par Obi-Wan Kenobi, Jedi Knight\par Obi-Wan Kenobi, Padawan Learner\par Obi-Wan Kenobi, Padawan Learner (V)\par Obi-Wan With Lightsaber\par Master Qui-Gon\par Master Qui-Gon (V)\par Qui-Gon Jinn\par Qui-Gon Jinn With Lightsaber\par Qui-Gon Jinn, Jedi Master
IsPulled: Sabe
Combo: Padme Naberrie + Jerus Jannick

Lore: Pit droids are used by Podracer pilots to assist in the maintenance of their racer. While a high standard is usually maintained, sometimes things can get out of hand.
Gametext: Use 3 Force to reveal opponent's hand. All cards opponent has 3 or more of in hand are lost. OR Use 1 Force to 'repair' your Podracer. OR Target a Podracer. Draw destiny. If destiny > Podracer's destiny number, target Podracer is 'damaged.'
Information: Pit Crews provides a versatile card for your podracing deck. It can be used offensively to make the opponent think twice about drawing race destiny, or it can be used to ensure that your own Podracer is in peak racing performance by quickly repairing any damage that you might encounter during the podrace.\par \par Or, if you draw this card after the podrace has already been decided, you can play it very effectively against swarm decks who might think their duplicates are protected by Yarna d'al' Gargan. But even if not playing against a swarm deck, this can give you a quick look at their hand to plan your next turn more effectively.
IsPulled: We Must Accelerate Our Plans

Lore: Manufactured by Serv-O-Droid on Cyrillia. Collapses into a compact form when hit on the nose.
Gametext: While at Podracer Bay, once during each of your control phases may lose 1 Force to target your Podracer. Place target's top race destiny in Lost Pile, and draw one race destiny. During any control phase may use 1 Force to 'repair' your Podracer.
Information: This little droid can definitely give you the edge in any podrace. He all but guarantees you will never have to keep any low destiny and ensures your Podracer stays in the lead. If you draw low, you can redraw it right away, and if it's still low, you can try again in your next control phase before you would draw for that turn. He also makes sure your Podracer is never damaged, ensuring that you'll never have to lose force to draw destiny, except for when you're redrawing yours with his other ability.

Lore: Advanced preparation in Podracing is usually the key to winning. A little extra work at the start can mean a lot in the long run.

Rules: (AR 1.7.1, B-12)\par Using the Lost function of this Interrupt card replaces a single race destiny draw. Additional race destiny draws may still be drawn normally.

Lore: Podracing demands constant attention to many variables as well as all opponents. Failure to do so can often result in reduced performance.
Gametext: USED: If you just verified opponent's Reserve Deck, search that Reserve Deck and place one Interrupt found there out of play. LOST: Lose 1 Force to remove a race destiny (random selection) from any Podracer and place it in owner's hand.
Information: The Used portion of this Interrupt is same as in Changing The Odds from the Light Side.\par -----\par This card has two very useful functions. A lot of popular Light decks use recycling interrupts like Fall of a Legend or Throw Me Another Charge which look through their decks to recycle high destiny interrupts. This card lets you punish your opponent for using cards just to look through their reserve deck or playing interrupts which don't really do anything. The Used portion of this card lets you look through their Reserve Deck and place any interrupt you find there out of play. If you're packing a couple of this interrupt, you can make your opponent think twice before looking for a Weather Vane.\par \par The Lost portion is also useful. If your Dark deck is podracing, you will definitely want to run multiples of this card. This interrupt will set Anakin's racer back, giving you more time to finish the race; even better, the card that goes back to the Light player's hand might be just enough to create a tie, which all but guarantees a Sebulba win.
IsPulled: We Must Accelerate Our Plans

Lore: On her assignment to kill Sharad Hett, Aurra used her patience and cunning to help track down the Jedi Master.
Gametext: Deploy on Aurra Sing. While Aurra is alone at a site, your total ability here = 0. During your move phase, may lose Effect to target an opponent's lightsaber present. Draw destiny. If destiny > 3, Aurra may 'steal' that lightsaber.
IsPulled: Twi'lek Advisor\par We Must Accelerate Our Plans
Combo: Quietly Observing + Aurra Sing

Lore: Accepted Obi-Wan Kenobi as his Padawan learner. Was given orders to protect Queen Amidala at all costs.
Gametext: Deploys -2 to Tatooine. Power +1 at same site as Maul. Once during a duel Qui-Gon is in, may cancel a duel destiny just drawn and cause a re-draw. Opponent's aliens are power -1 at same site. Immune to attrition.
Information: Qui-Gon Jinn personas are:\par \par Master Qui-Gon\par Master Qui-Gon (V)\par Qui-Gon Jinn\par Qui-Gon Jinn With Lightsaber\par Qui-Gon Jinn, Jedi Master\par -----\par (Light side Icon)\par \par Qui-gon Jinn has the distinction of being the only Light Side character to participate in armed combat during the Tatooine-based scenes of The Phantom Menace. This combat was in the form of a brief duel with Darth Maul. It should come as no surprise that Qui-gon's gametext reflects this conflict with Maul. When at a site with Maul, Qui-gon gets a power bonus that brings him to the same level as his nemesis, allowing them to start a battle on even ground. In addition, if Maul is bold enough to start a duel against Qui-gon, the Jedi Master has the ability to cancel a destiny draw and cause a redraw. While this text doesn't give Qui-gon an advantage in the number of duel destinies drawn, it does give him the opportunity to potentially reduce a high Dark Side destiny or increase an unfortunate destiny draw of his own.\par \par Finally, Qui-gon Jinn is able to reduce the effectiveness of opponent's aliens at the same site by reducing their power by 1. This trick can be very useful when presented with a swarm of aliens, bringing their high power down to a more manageable level.
IsPulled: Padme Naberrie\par Tatooine: City Outskirts
Combo: Qui-Gon Jinn + A Jedi's Patience
Cancels: A duel destiny to cause a redraw.

Lore: Qui-Gon was forced to defend himself when Darth Maul tracked them down on Tatooine. He was barely able to escape, in order to fight another day.
Gametext: Deploy on Qui-Gon. May add 1 to Force drain where present. May target a character or creature. Draw two destiny. Target hit, and its forfeit = 0, if total destiny > defense value.
Information: Qui-Gon Jinn's lightsaber 'personas' are:\par \par Qui-Gon Jinn's Lightsaber\par Qui-Gon's Lightsaber\par Qui-Gon Jinn With Lighsaber\par -----\par 'Qui-Gon's Lightsaber' has (better) destiny of 5 but does not add to drain.\par \par Continuing in the great tradition of the most powerful weapons in the game, the Light side now has another powerful unique lightsaber to add to their arsenal.\par \par In addition to the always strong "ordinary" uses, like adding to a Force drain or cleaving targets like a ginsu knife, this elegant tool has a few additional benefits. Many of the new "Jedi helpers" (A Jedi's Concentration, A Jedi's Focus, and A Jedi's Patience) require your Knight or Master to be armed with a lightsaber, and thus Qui-Gon will be at his most efficient when he has his. You'll also find that Qui-Gon armed with his weapon is a tank, and when he holds it he joins Jedi Luke as one of the few Light side characters able to safely hold down a site all by himself.
IsPulled: Gift Of The Mentor\par Qui-Gon Jinn, Jedi Master when lightsaber is in Lost Pile
MatchingWeapon: Master Qui-Gon\par Master Qui-Gon (V)\par Qui-Gon Jinn\par Qui-Gon Jinn, Jedi Master

Lore: Strange female Snivvian who frequents the cantina daily. Betrayed her loved ones, who then left her on Tatooine to die. Everything she's ever cared about is now gone or dead.
Gametext: Adds 2 to power of anything she pilots. During a battle involving Rachalt, whenever opponent draws an Interrupt for destiny may use 2 Force to cause that Interrupt to be lost. While armed with a weapon at a site, Force drain +1 here.
Information: Although the 8th Snivvian in Star Wars CCG  Rachalt is the first pilot of her species to make it onto a card.\par \par Her lore tells a story almost as harsh as her features, but her game text provides an ability you may find useful! Sandwiched between a little drain-adding text and a pretty standard piloting bonus is a nice interrupt-removal text. Whenever your opponent draws an Interrupt card for any destiny during battle, use 2 Force and throw it out! The destiny draw still counts (it is not canceled!), but that pesky recycling 5 can be taken a little further away from a player who is a good destiny tracker.\par \par You may also think that devoting a weapon to Rachalt isn't really worth the effort for a Force drain +1 (even with Inconsequential Losses), but don't forget that if the opponent isn't running Menace Fades, Honor Of The Jedi, or Jedi Test #1, this is a handy way to turn a site with no Dark Side icons into a pesky "pinger." Of course, Rachalt ain't too great at avoiding weapon fire herself -- so keep her safe aboard something enclosed, and lo and behold, her +1 to drains still works! Maybe this Dark Side uncommon will find a place in a few of your decks after all?

Lore: Bad tempered Dug from Pixelito. He was about to turn Jar Jar into orange goo, until Anakin intervened.
Gametext: Once per battle, may use 1 Force to target opponent's character of ability < 3 at same site; target is power -3 for remainder of turn. If present with Jar Jar, during your control phase may use 3 Force to place Jar Jar out of play.
Information: If Jar Jar is the problem, then Sebulba is the answer. Sebulba can permanently deal with Jar Jar if the Gungan is foolish enough to wander over to the same location as Sebulba. There won't be any more Brisky Morning Munchen once Sebulba is finished turning Jar Jar into orange goo!\par \par Sebulba is also a solid choice for any alien based decks. 4 power for 3 deploy is a good deal, but with his ability to reduce an opposing character's power, it's almost as if he had 7 power! And he can help his good buddy Snoova and his Vibro Ax capture large hairy Wookies from time to time, too, making Chewie an easy mark.
IsPulled: He Always Wins! (V)\par Ni Chuba Na??

Lore: Some hidden modifications mean Sebulba's Podracer doesn't conform to race specifications. The duplicitous Dug has equipped it with a flame emitter that can fry other Podracers.
Gametext: Deploy on Podrace Arena. Adds 3 to each of your race destinies here. If you and your opponent have the same race total, may use 2 Force. Opponent draws no race destiny for remainder of turn (may only be used once for any race total).
Information: If you're a Dark side player, and you want to win a podrace, then this is your best choice. He adds 3 to each of his race destinies, so depending on the destiny in your deck, he will usually finish the race for you in 4 turns.\par \par To make it even more likely he'll win, he also gets a head start. Since he can prevent the opponent from drawing racing destiny if he's tied, you will always get a head start at the beginning of the race when both racing totals are zero. If your opponent manages to catch up to you, there's no worries, because you can stop the opponent from drawing destiny every time you're tied. This podracer is full of dirty tricks!

Lore: Mother of Anakin Skywalker. As Anakin grew, Shmi realized her son was special. Did her best to hide his abilities from Watto.
Gametext: Deploys for free to Slave Quarters. Once per game may take [Tatooine] Threepio into hand from Reserve Deck; reshuffle. While in a battle at a site, subtracts one from each of opponent's battle destiny draws.
Information: Everybody loves reducing opponent's battle destiny, and Shmi is no exception. If your opponent is drawing multiple battle destiny, Shmi can lessen the damage from each one. She can also sometimes prevent you from losing anything at all. Many times your opponent will draw a one for battle destiny, which normally would force you to lose something, but Shmi will reduce that one to a zero, saving all your characters.\par \par She also lets you get Threepio With His Parts Showing from your Reserve Deck once per game. While that might not sound like a great benefit, the two characters work great together in battle. Threepio lets you put a card from your hand into your Used Pile, and when with Shmi in battle he lets you put the top card from your Used Pile on to your Reserve Deck which can enable you to get a guaranteed weapon hit, or any other action which requires a high destiny.
Pulls: Threepio With His Parts Showing
IsPulled: Tatooine: Slave Quarters
Combo: Shmi + Threepio With His Parts Showing\par Destiny tracking never so easy.

Lore: At his peak, no one could stand up to the Dark Lord of the Sith. His superior tactics devastated those who opposed him.
Gametext: USED: During a battle, lose one of your lightsabers in that battle to cause all non-unique aliens present to be lost. LOST: If a duel was just initiated, draw 2 destiny. Opponent draws 3 destiny. If the player with the lower total loses the duel, that player loses 6 Force.

Lore: Patrol droids utilized by the Sith. Each droid has several multispectral imaging devices and a communications package. Used by Maul to track down Amidala.
Gametext: When deployed, immediately retrieve 1 Force. Limit 1 Sith Probe Droid per location. If present with Amidala during your control phase may use 3 Force to relocate this Sith Probe Droid to Maul's site, and relocate Maul to same site as Amidala.
Information: A no-brainer for any "Capture the Queen" deck, these little mechanoids have a number of outstanding features. Their retrieval text means that playing with a few of them can help out any deck. When you have a crucial card on the top of your Lost Pile, or if you had to forfeit a vital character on your opponent's turn, then the deployment of a Sith Probe Droid will allow for its rescue.\par \par They also serve as the ultimate hunters and trackers of Amidala. You don't have to play with too many copies, either, since the Epic Event If The Trace Is Correct allows them to be "downloaded." Get 2 or 3 roaming the same planet as the Queen, and she will be unable to escape the reach of the Sith Apprentice for long.
IsPulled: Captain Piett\par If The Trace Was Correct
Rules: (AR 1.7.1, B-14)\par The "limit 1 per location" text on this droid works as per the operative rules (see Characteristics - Operatives, Ap. D). A player may not voluntarily deploy or move a Sith Probe Droid to or across a location where another Sith Probe Droid is located. If this should ever happen accidentally, the owner must choose one to be lost. If they belong to different owners, the droid lost is determined randomly.

And what greater way to drive like a madman than podracing at the Podrace Arena?\par \par But if you want your deck to speed up on podracing, don't forget to pack Start Your Engines! and a Podracer to get a jump start. Sebulba's Podracer is a fan favorite, but don't preclude Teemto Pagalies' Podracer, which can race pretty well on its own too.\par \par Check out the Light Side version of the Podrace Arena for a few additional tips!

Most likely, you will want to include Podrace Prep and Anakin's Podracer to get a boost for podracing.\par \par But don't forget the game text of the site. It is a great way to hide your weaker characters for the first few turns. You can deploy support characters such as Mirax Terrik or Leesub Sirln to help you manipulate your deck or do some direct damage to your opponent. Just watch out for local indigenous creatures like Bubo.

Information: Not the greatest of locations judging by the Force icons, but looks are deceiving as they say. If you are heavily into podracing, this site can be a great boon. As long as you control the site, you can swap a card once every turn at just about anytime. So, now you can purposely lose high destiny cards and switch them as soon as you lose it.\par \par But to get better use of this site, you should use Entering The Arena. Not only will the interrupt fetch the site, it will help you keep the site clear of any opposing forces. Also, since Entering The Arena has high destiny, it would be ideal to swap it with the top race destiny to ensure that you win the race.
IsPulled: A Weakness Can Be Found\par Diplomatic Mission To Alderaan\par Entering The Arena\par Mindful Of The Future\par Yarna d'al' Gargan (V)

Gametext: Once per game may deploy Shmi here from Reserve Deck; reshuffle.   If Watto present, Force drain +1 here.
LightSideText: Once per game may deploy Shmi here from Reserve Deck; reshuffle.
DarkSideText: If Watto present, Force drain +1 here.
Information: Cool! Another 2/0 site like Obi-Wan's Hut for Tatooine! With "Shmi's Hut" you can get her out to quickly set up for Threepio With His Parts Showing. Although both characters are not very strong, their strength lies in their game text.\par \par One good use of another 0 Dark Side Force icon location is to set up Tatooine so that you can control where the actions take place. By placing locations in a certain order, you can make Tatooine into a rat trap for the Dark Side. You can put one battleground in between the Slave Quarters and Obi-Wan's Hut. Doing so will force the opponent to deploy to the middle and if they try to escape, you can nab them at either non-battleground with less fear of a counterattack. Another way is to put both Slave Quarters and Obi-Wan's Hut together to create a partial haven for utility characters (e.g., Figrin D'an or Oola).
Pulls: Shmi Skywalker

Lore: An isolated camp protected by Obi-Wan and Captain Panaka was established at the Queen's starship while Qui-Gon searched for a way to repair the leaking hyperdrive.
Gametext: Deploy on table. Each non-battleground docking bay generates no more than one Force for either player. Opponent's aliens deploy +1 on Tatooine (or +2 if non-unique or to same Tatooine site as your Jedi, or +4 if both). (Immune to Alter.)
Information: Startable with Heading For The Medical Frigate.\par -----\par First, while you have The Camp out, your opponent will be less likely to activate a high amount of Force on turn 2 like in the past. No more camping at non-battleground docking bays with some cheap characters using the Imperial Arrest Order + Mobilization Points combo. If they want to, they must pay the price... occupy or control a battleground docking bay instead. Some will say that this will hurt decks like Ralltiir Operations, but that deck worked fine without that combo, and note that it affects both players. This card puts the "Wars" back in Star Wars. :)\par \par Second, this card mitigates the bonuses the Dark Side reaps with Scum And Villany. Alien base decks can still be popular but they won't get the nearly free deploy that they used to get. Most aliens will end up costing what is printed on the card, but they should stay far away from the Jedi since that is Maul's and Vader's department.
IsPulled: The Signal\par We Wish To Board At Once
Rules: (AR 1.7.1, B-15)\par The deploy modifiers listed within brackets all apply to your opponent's aliens when they are deploying to Tatooine only.

Lore: "That name no longer has any meaning..."
Gametext: USED: If your Imperial of ability > 2 just won a battle, randomly take into hand one card stacked on I Feel The Conflict. (Immune to Sense.) LOST: If Vader in battle, subtract 2 from each of opponent's battle destiny draws.
Information: Luke: "Your thoughts betray you, Father. I feel the good in you... the conflict."\par Vader: "There is no conflict."\par \par Gotta love cards that you can play during a game as if you were quoting from the movie! Like in the movie, you will also get to respond to the Light Side's "I Feel The Conflict" and take back a card to prevent Vader from becoming Anakin again.\par \par Players will compare this to the Light Side counterpart Our Only Hope (from the DSII set) but there is a subtle difference. Note that the Lost part of this card has no special restrictions like Our Only Hope. This means that you can send Vader into battle even against Luke - as long as your opponent isn't playing There Is Good In Him (TIGIH) - and still keep Vader alive by reducing attrition a bit.

Lore: Protocol Droid designed by Anakin in order to help his mother. C-3PO was not to be sold when Anakin left with Qui-Gon Jinn for Coruscant.
Gametext: If in a battle with Shmi at a site, once per battle may place top card of your Used Pile on top of your Reserve Deck. Once per turn may place a card from hand on Used Pile to draw top card from Reserve Deck.
Information: C-3PO personas are:\par \par Artoo & Threepio\par C-3PO (See-Threepio)\par See-Threepio\par Threepio\par Threepio With His Parts Showing\par -----\par The Episode 1 version of Threepio is a great card for anyone who likes to have full control over their deck. Threepio shares Mirax Terrik's ability to circulate high destiny cards back into your deck and replace them with new cards from the Reserve Deck. What's even nicer about Threepio's ability is that, unlike Mirax, his ability can be used for free, and instead of placing the card on the bottom of the Used Pile, he places it on the top of the Used Pile for easier tracking when your Reserve Deck is larger.\par \par The other nice thing about Threepio's ability to place a high destiny card on top of your Used Pile is that if he's in a battle with Shmi, he can then take that high destiny card and place it on top of your Reserve Deck, ensuring a nice pull for weapon or battle destiny. And since Shmi can download Threepio right out of the Reserve Deck, the odds of you having them in a battle together are pretty good.\par \par The fact that this is a persona of C-3PO also has enormous benefits. Because most versions of C-3PO have only been strong in specialized decks, many of his support cards are quite powerful. For example, Were You Looking For Me? is a handy 5 Destiny Used Interrupt that allows you to pull Threepio and/or another protocol droid (like R-3PO) from your Reserve Deck. You can also use the same Interrupt as a Lost Interrupt to either retrieve Threepio from the Lost Pile or to add a battle destiny when Threepio is helping his friends out in battle (two battle destiny if he happens to have a few furry friends with him). Unlike most "back" cards, this card is very appealing because it's recyclable, free, high destiny, and has the battle destiny bonus.\par \par There are tons of other C-3PO suppport cards, including the ever-popular How Did We Get Into This Mess?, but one of my favorites is Artoo, I Have A Bad Feeling About This, which has three different uses, the best of which allows you to squash your opponent's battle destiny completely if both Artoo and C-3PO are together in battle. Put Shmi, Artoo and Threepio together in a battle, and with the right support cards you can really put the hurt on the Dark Side.
IsPulled: Seeking An Audience\par Seeking An Audience (V)\par Shmi Skywalker\par Were You Looking For Me?
Combo: Threepio With His Parts Showing + Chewie With Blaster Rifle\par Chewie With Blaster Rifle adds one battle destiny if with C-3P0.\par -----\par Threepio With His Parts Showing + Eventually You'll Lose

Lore: Anakin needed all the help he could get to evade Sebulba's tactics.
Gametext: USED: If your character was just targeted by a weapon, opponent must use 2 Force or the targeting is canceled. LOST: Cancel Hit Racer or Podracer Collision.
Information: This interrupt is a great alternative to Put That Down from the Cloud City set. While it doesn't guarantee the ability to cancel a weapon from targeting one of your characters, this version is much cheaper - it's free! Instead of having you use 3 Force, you make your opponent use 2 Force or they missed with their weapon.\par \par As an added bonus, you can also use it to prevent your opponent from using tricks like Hit Racer or Podracer Collision while your Podracer attempts to take the checkered flag.
IsPulled: We Wish To Board At Once
Combo: Too Close For Comfort + Put That Down: A bit excessive, but this will really frustrate your opponent when they use 2 Force and miss regardless.

Lore: When Qui-Gon got away, Maul knew it would only be a matter of time until the two of them would meet again.
Gametext: If opponent just initiated a duel against one of your non-captive Jedi, deploy on that Jedi. Cancel the duel and relocate this Jedi to an adjacent site. Your duel destiny draws are each +1. (Immune to Control.)
Information: There are two major types of anti-dueling cards - "escape the duel" cards and "help win the duel" cards. This Immediate Effect walks a fine line between them both!\par \par Initially, it provides you with a duel canceler. Unlike A Jedi's Resilience, though, you must make your cancel decision as the duel is initiated. This one does not give you the option to await the outcome!\par \par But it does come with an added benefit. Now that you know your Jedi is being targeted, and your assailant has been drawn out (most likely? the duel-happy Darth Maul), use this knowledge to your advantage to put all your Jedi on high alert! All your duel destiny draws are now +1, regardless which character is under attack. And it will last as long as you can keep the Jedi with What Was It? on him alive!
IsPulled: Don't Do That Again\par Don't Do That Again - Defensive Shield\par Don't Do That Again (V) - Defensive Shield\par Harc Seff (V)\par The Signal\par We Wish To Board At Once

Lore: Kadas'sa'Nikto. \b Smuggler\b0  who stole from shipments going in and out of Jabba's Palace. Part of Jabba's sail barge crew. Not trusted by anyone.
Gametext: Adds 2 to power of anything he pilots. Opponent's combat vehicles are each power -2 at same site. Once per game, may take Mechanical Failure and/or Free Ride into hand from Reserve Deck; reshuffle.
Information: First point of note is that he is a smuggler. This means an option for your Watch Your Step deck. What's more, he's a pilot, capable of Kessel Running if Dash is on holidays. There are a few other related benefits for smugglers such as cheap deploy to Kashyyyk, or meeting a requirement in your Profit deck so you can play Jabba's Palace sabacc! Beware a Death Mark, though.\par \par His text provides him with a great all-round ability against opponent's vehicular threats. Power -2 against combat vehicles at same site (note that Yotts does not have to be present, so feel free to hide him inside a vehicle of your own!), and a once-per-game grab of Free Ride (steal a vehicle) and/or Mechanical Failure (Lateral Damage a vehicle!). If you are playing either of these cards, Yotts may beg for consideration!
Pulls: Free Ride\par Free Ride & Endor Celebration\par Mechanical Failure
IsPulled: Soth Petikkin (when at a Jabba's Palace site you control).

Lore: Echo Base was no match for the Imperial war machine.
Gametext: Deploy on table if 5th marker also on table. During your control phase, opponent loses 1 Force for each marker site you occupy with an AT-AT. Once per game, may take both Walker Garrison and 3rd Marker into hand from Reserve Deck; reshuffle. (Immune to Alter.)
Information: Startable with Prepared Defenses.\par -----\par This card heralds the return of the almighty Walker Garrison deck. Being able to start this effect with Prepared Defenses is a great boost to this classic deck type. On your first turn, you can immediately go and grab the 3rd Marker, which combined with the 5th Marker gives you 4 red icons and a +1 Force Drain location, while the Light Side only gets one blue icon from you in the bargain. Plus, you are guaranteed to have a Walker Garrison in hand right from the get-go, so you are all set to drain like mad once you've got all your Walkers in position.\par \par The best part of this card, however, is its ability to deal direct damage just by occupying Hoth marker sites with AT-ATs, which any self-respecting Walker Garrison deck has in abundance. If you choose No Escape as one of your starting effects, this direct damage will not be cancelled by Honor of the Jedi, which is a good thing since your force drains at non-battlegrounds will be negated by that powerful Light Side card. Be sure to pack a couple Presence of the Force to help turn those Marker Sites into battlegrounds and add to your drains in the bargain.\par \par For a third starting effect for this deck type, you probably want to start with Imperial Arrest Order. This will give a big boost to all your Walker pilots, and allow you to deploy the Hoth: Echo Docking Bay right away, a great place to plop a Walker to help drain with Walker Garrison. Unfortunately, the Docking Bay isn't a Marker Site, but it's still a great battleground to drain at with your Walkers. An alternative starting effect is Imperial Decree, which is pretty easy to keep active with this deck and which can really hurt those cowardly Rebels.
Pulls: Hoth: Defensive Perimeter\par Walker Garrison\par Walker Garrison (V)
IsPulled: Twi'lek Advisor\par We Must Accelerate Our Plans
Rules: (AR 1.7.1, B-17)\par "Occupy with an AT-AT" means that you must occupy the location, and the AT-AT cannot be unpiloted.

CardName: You'll Find I'm Full Of Surprises
Lore: Even though he wasn't fully prepared to face the Dark Lord of the Sith, Luke rushed to save his friends.
Gametext: If Luke and Vader present at same site, use 1 Force to initiate a duel between them. Either is power +2 if armed with a lightsaber. Draw destiny. Opponent draws two destiny. Both players add power. Loser is placed out of play.
Information: At first glance, you might say, "Hey, why would I play this card?" After all, although it gives the Light Side a chance to duel, it automatically starts you at a disadvantage, giving the Dark Side two destiny to your one. And although having Luke placed out of play might seem appealing versus a Bring Him Before Me deck, you can't play this card when that Objective is out (due to the Objective's card text).\par \par So what's the point? Well, if you're willing to devote a few extra cards to your Mains deck, this card can certainly be an unwelcome surprise for the Dark Side. Most decks carry a Vader or three, so devoting a bit of your strategy to this card can usually be effective. And it is a 6 Destiny card, so it will always have that bit of usefulness. Now, play two or three of these cards in your deck, and you've got some of the high destiny you need to succeed with this card.\par \par Also, pack Courage of Skywalker to give you another destiny to even things out a bit with the old Dark Lord. And let's not forget Glancing Blow, which allows you to cancel one of the Dark Side's duelling destiny draws or, if you play You'll Find I'm Full of Surprises during the weapons segment of a battle, you can use Glancing Blow to nail Vader's power, knocking it to an unmodifiable zero, which means he won't even get the +2 power from holding his lightsaber granted by the Interrupt. Suddenly, Vader's chances of winning have become quite slim, and it looks like he's going away for a very long time.\par \par Having this sort of a side strategy not only lets you beat up Luke's favorite sparring partner, but also gives you a plethora of cards to defend yourself during duels initiated by the Dark Side with such cards as Epic Duel or new cards like Darth Maul.\par \par Some new Tatooine cards that can help you win the day versus Vader include A Jedi's Focus: which lets you add the destiny of the top card of the Lost Pile to your total, A Jedi's Patience: which lets you redraw one of your bad duelling destiny draws, and most importantly, A Jedi's Resilience, which allows you to cancel a duel AFTER you've lost it AND take the duelling card back into your hand!\par \par But watch out for the new Dark Side card, Lightsaber Parry, or your duel might suddenly become very expensive!
